Posts.Content: Will your chemo unit take them? I got my wig stand from there - free, after someone had donated it when they had finished with it. People also donate their wigs once they've finished with them. Also, the Macmillan unit in the hospital where I had my radiotherapy had second hand wigs.
Posts.Title: Charity?

Posts.Content: Hi Julia i was referred to the lymph oedema clinic 2 weeks after my surgery, on the basis that I had fluid in my arm, and the surgeon thought it probably was fluid from the op, but referred me anyway just in case. I don't think it can be too early to do something about it, the earlier you start treating it, the better the outcome. If your consultant says you have lymph oedema in the breast then the earlier something is done about it the better. How bad does it have to be before he will refer you? I hate it when people are told they are not bad enough to be treated.
Posts.Title: question

Posts.Content: 2 Have a happy birthday - if you can.
Posts.Title: Angry !

Posts.Content: 4 I didn't come and see you because I didn't want to intrude on your privacy!!
Posts.Title: Angry !

Posts.Content: My drain removal wasn't at all painful. I had my op on a Tuesday and the drains were taken out on the Friday, so only a couple of days. It will depend on how much is being drained as to when they will come out. Your mum will be told what to look out for. I had a V shaped cushion too, and slept for a couple of nights in a semi sitting position, the cushion made sure I was comfortable. It's really important your mum does her exercises to keep mobile, especially if she is to have radiotherapy afterwards.
Posts.Title: Advice please-Mastectomy with lymph node clearance

Posts.Content: Hi I use a ball too, not for stiffness, although I'm sure that using it is also helping to prevent stiffness, but for lymphoedema. It was suggested by a lymphoedema nurse. As part of my exercises I squeeze a ball - mine's a dog toy, quite soft but firm enough to do good. Also when I flew recently I took the ball with me and squeezed the ball while resting my arm on the head rest of the seat in front. You can also get 'spiky' balls - I think they call them acupuncture balls - to roll in your hand; they'd probably help too.
Posts.Title: Sore hands - revelation!

Posts.Content: Dexa scan results went to my radiotherapy consultant. I also got a copy of the scan results in the post, GP also got the results. A few weeks later I got a letter from the consultant telling me to make an appointment with the GP to discuss the results.
Posts.Title: dexa scan results

Posts.Content: This has come up just at the right time for me, as for the last few days I've had heartburn in the evenings. Seem to be okay during the day at the moment but it woke me up last night. I wondered if it was all the painkillers I've been having, also wondered if it could be the chemo, but It's 9 weeks since my last chemo, my stomach was mostly absolutely fine while on chemo, but I'm not taking the stomach protecting tablets now. Will bring it up with Macmillan nurse next time I speak to her, but glad to hear I'm not the only one.
Posts.Title: Terrible tummy :(

Posts.Content: Hi, looks like noone has replied yet. Don't know if my experience is relevant, but I had balance issues rather than lack of mobility due to pain, after treatment ended. I didn't actually fall over, but came pretty near a few times, and had quite a bit of vertigo. I can't help with the pain you're getting from your meds, but exercises can help with the balance issue, and hopefully stop you falling over. I went to a gentle movement class which included exercises for balance and I have some I can do at home. I still very occasionally feel as though I'm going to fall but it's not as bad as before. Hope someone comes along who has more relevant experience.
Posts.Title: Mobility issues and coordination since finishing treatment

Posts.Content: I used Aveeno cream all through. It was thoroughly approved of by the radiotherapy staff, and I still use it now for general moisturising. R1 and R2 are supposed to be good but there's no point in stressing about it when other things are available. I was "lucky" that I had my radiotherapy in the summer and did not have any reconstruction to cope with. I let the air get at it as much as possible, and went braless, and had no problems at all. I'd have thought that Aloe vera for cooling, followed by a good moisturiser would be fine, and a lot cheaper!
Posts.Title: R1 R2 for radiotherapy

Posts.Content: When my hair got to about the same length as yours I went to my hairdresser and asked her if it was ready for a cut or whether to leave it a bit. She said to leave it a bit, so I carried on using my wig for a while until it was long enough to cut. Try asking your hairdresser; mine was very helpful. You are very lucky if you have thick hair, mine has always been very fine and there's not been a lot of it, but it's even more sparse now and my scalp shows through quite clearly sometimes. I even considered getting another wig to wear.
Posts.Title: hair regrowth ahhhh what to do with it ?

Posts.Content: I only have two cups of green tea a day. It's got caffeine in so I don't drink it after about 4 o'clock  I've seen white tea in the supermarket, will give it a try. Peppermint tea is one of my favourites, and chamomile as a bedtime drink. The exercise programme I do at our leisure centre is supported by Macmillan and runs at quite a few places in our area, so I imagine that similar schemes run in other parts of the country. Until I started it I'd never been to a gym and imagined it would be full of young, slim, Lycra clad fit people, but the first time I went there were quite a few people, older, and larger than me, so I felt quite comfortable in my trackside bottoms and trainers. The gym also does GP referrals.
Posts.Title: Lifestyle changes?

Posts.Content: I always thought that pre-op assessments were just to check that you were fit to undergo surgery and to check a few things for the anaesthetist. I had weight,height, bloods done and a check on some medication I was taking that needed to be stopped before the op, and I asked a few questions about what would happen on the actual day. The actual procedure was decided weeks before when I saw the surgeon. I only saw my surgeon once before the operation day., approx a month before it.; there was no other contact before the pre op assessment. If you can't get hold of your BC nurse then ring the surgeon's secretary and see if you can speak to him, and keep trying the BC nurse. This is all very worrying for you, not what you need a couple of days before an op. I do hope you get it sorted tomorrow.
Posts.Title: NO DISCUSSION

Posts.Content: Do you know which of the two procedures they are planning to do ?
Posts.Title: NO DISCUSSION

Posts.Content: I'm almost at that stage. Last radiotherapy tomorrow, and then that's it, apart from the Anastrozole that I start taking in a few weeks time. I've been concentrating so hard on just getting through each stage - chemo, surgery, radiotherapy, that I've not had time to reflect on what's happened to me, and hoping it doesn't suddenly overwhelm me a few weeks down the line. I've not had my appointment through for my follow up yet so that's the next benchmark.  When we were going through a particularly bad time when my daughter was younger several people said to me 'How on earth do you cope, I couldn't'. My answer was that we coped because we had to, there was no choice, and it's true for the last 8 months. As far as I was concerned there was no choice; I wanted to live so I coped with all the side effects, somehow. There were times when I thought I didn't want to go on, but when I thought what the alternative was I gritted my teeth and put up with it.
Posts.Title: Said my goodbyes

Posts.Content: Well, it's all finished. My husband took me out for lunch to celebrate, nice restaurant overlooking the sea. Funny I don't feel relieved, exhilarated or anything, just a sense of "now I can start to get better" . Not got a follow up appt yet, should be for a few weeks time. It'll be really strange not getting up at 6 to get to the hospital. Just Anastrozole to go, told to start it in about 6 weeks. Spenfold1, I know what you mean by the stabby pains, they're so strong sometimes that they make me jump! Keep going everyone, you can get there!!!
Posts.Title: Said my goodbyes

Posts.Content: I'm so glad you got it sorted. It's so worrying when you don't know what's happening, or why. Best of luck for Monday.
Posts.Title: NO DISCUSSION

Posts.Content: Well, as soon as I was diagnosed I gave up alcohol. I didn't drink very much anyway - shared a bottle of wine with my husband on a Friday was about it - but I feel so much better for stopping that. I can't say I've not touched a drop; my husband likes to have a glass of lager with his meal sometimes and I've just had a sip from his glass, but that's it. Since my treatment finished I've started to exercise. I go to the local leisure centre once, or occasionally twice a week to do an exercise programme specially for those being treated or have finished treatment for cancer. One is a gym session and the other a circuit session. I also go to the local cancer care centre once a week to do yoga, and I try to have a good walk at least once a week - we have dogs so I take them out. I now drink green tea. Cut down ordinary tea and coffee to one a day and the rest of the time I drink green tea or herbal tea. I've added nuts to my diet I want to lose weight, and am struggling to do so. I'm on Anastrozole which can make you gain weight so I watch it carefully. I'm not really gaining weight, but not losing it either. I am just on the borderline between normal and overweight so just need to lose a bit. Those are the main changes I've made and I'm sure there are lots more I could do, but they all have to be introduced slowly and one at a time or I won't be able to keep it up!
Posts.Title: Lifestyle changes?

Posts.Content: I have lymphodema in my arm, and lately found there is some in my chest and side. In the last few months I've had kinesio taping and MLD for the lymphodema and am now having low level laser light therapy for fibrosis. The kinesio taping and MLD are not alternatives to the compression garments, but are complementary - or at least that's how it is for me.  I went to the clinic once a week for 3 weeks to have the kinesio tape put on. I was told to try to keep it on for 5 days then to take it off. I took my husband with me on the last one so he could see how to apply it, and I was told I could do it myself from then on. I also took photos so I knew where it was supposed to go. It appeared to be stuck on with superglue!!! My nurse said to keep a little spray bottle of baby oil (or any oil) and spray it on the tape. Leave it until it's soaked in and it comes off really easily. But I still had to wear my sleeve every day like before. Then I had MLD twice a week for 3 weeks - after the second one each week, over the weekend, they kinesio taped me as well, and I wore the sleeve just as usual. Now I'm having the laser therapy, and after the one this week I also had kinesio tape. So, don't assume that it's either/or. I found that whatever other treatment I had I still had to wear my sleeve. I also do lymphatic drainage exercises every day.
Posts.Title: Lymphodema in arm

Posts.Content: Hi I've got lymphodema too. I can remember crying all through the first appointment with the lymphodema service when I was told it was a lifelong condition and I'd have to wear a sleeve every day. I too now put on my sleeve just like all my other clothes; it's very comfortable and when I went for my checkup a while ago, my arm had gone down even further. I do simple lymphatic drainage exercises every day - some I got from the internet, some were given me by the lymph clinic. I've had kinesio taping which helps, and I've just finished a course of Manual lymphatic drainage (provided by the lymph clinic) because I found out I also had lymphodema in my chest and side.  I went away in February (to Norway, so I didn't have to worry about heat!!!!) and my doctor gave me some antibiotics to take with me. I just went and asked for them. Wore my sleeve on the plane and took a small soft rubber ball with me and squeezed it occasionally while we were travelling, just to encourage the lymph to move.
Posts.Title: Lymphodema in arm

Posts.Content: Hi Jan Yes, Crystaljuju is right, the tape raises the skin slightly so the lymph can drain more easily, so it would be counterproductive to wear the compression sleeve over it. I have the compression sleeve on my arm and the kinesio tape on my chest and side. I would love to be discharged from the lymph clinic and had hoped to be told this time that I needn't wear the sleeve all the time as my arm had gone down almost to normal. But they still said to wear it all day (I can take it off for a few hours if I'm going out somewhere and want to bare my arms), and certainly at the moment it looks as though I shall be going there for the foreseeable future - October check up appointment already made.
Posts.Title: Lymphodema in arm

Posts.Content: I have rib pain, and it is driving me mad. I have a few "trigger points" which, when I press them are extremely painful. The pain also extends down my side sometimes. I cannot wear a bra, and have to be careful even with the little crop tops I wear to go out. I even have to be careful about what goes round my waist - it has to be very soft and elasticated. It means I cannot wear my prosthesis and as I am quite large on the non mastectomy side I look ridiculous. I have mentioned it in the past but now have gone to my GP since it's bugging me so much (don't need to tell you that I'm also frightened) and she's sent me for an xray to check whether there's anything that can be seen. Ibuprofen doesn't work, neither does paracetamol. I've got some cocodamol and tramadol left from when I was having treatment and will try them. I'm sorry you're suffering with this, but I'm also so glad to hear of someone else who has it.
Posts.Title: Long term impact of chemo?

Posts.Content: I had a lot of pain from my PICC line, and unfortunately it did turn out to be a clot and an infection and I spent 3 nights in hospital. Do you have a temperature as well? And is your arm swelling? I'd certainly get it checked straight away.
Posts.Title: Why is my PICC a Pain...???

Posts.Content: Hi Since I finished my treatment I've had a series of minor things go wrong, one of which was vaginosis, for which the treatment is usually oestrogen, which I can't have. I have Replens which I use sometimes. The nurse also recommended letting the air get to it as much as possible, and suggested that my trousers might be contributing to the discomfort (nice and warm just the way the bacteria like it). The ones I had on and which I'd been wearing almost constantly as they were comfortable were man made fibres. I switched to wearing skirts much more often, wore cotton or linen trousers as much as possible, and kept my "bad" ones just to wear occasionally. I sometimes get into my night things in the evening with no knickers so the air can get to the area. I have had some recurrence of it, but not as bad as the first one.
Posts.Title: Letrazole side effect

Posts.Content: Have not yet set foot outside the door today, but yesterday was great. Got out of bed thinking about what I had to do that day - lots of admiin (groan) washing (groan), preparing for daughter coming end of week (hooray). At 9:40 just as I was in the shower, the phone rang. Eldest daughter asking us if we were around. Granddaughter (age 3) had declared she wanted to go and see granny and grandpa. Hooray!! Abandon all thoughts of admin. Although not a nice day, cloudy, misty etc, daughter fancied a walk on the beach. Did we want to go? My feet were hurting and I didn't know how far I'd  manage but I said I'd go if grandpa came too. So off we went, and I had a lovely time. We meandered up the beach, jumping in puddles and sliding in the mud. Little one one rode on grandpa's shoulders on the way back and loudly said "Good morning" to everyone we met. She makes me laugh so much so when we got back the cobwebs were thoroughly blown away and I'd forgotten all my troubles!! Not the sort of walk that helps to lose weight or get fit, but my mood and feeling of wellbeing was much improved!!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Just back from my first walk for a while - have had visitors for a few days so any walking has been round town. It takes about 30secs to get to our usual walking place, and about 20 mins to walk round it at a reasonable pace. It's just taken me over half an hour to do it, due to the plodding old canine who gives a really good impression of not really knowing where she is or which way she is supposed to go. We found her straying in the mountains nearly 10 years ago. We were told then she was a minimum of 5 years old, but could possibly be 7, which makes her at least 15 and possibly 16 or 17. As well as being really old with very wobbly back legs she has dementia, so when she goes out I need to keep a good eye on her in case she forgets where she is and goes off in a different direction!  But at least I got out into the cold fresh air and feel batter for it.
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: I developed lymphodema immediately after the surgery and was referred pretty quickly to the lymphodema clinic. I wear a sleeve all day every day, and I was shown how to do simple lymphatic drainage exercises, and I found some other exercises on the internet that I also do. I do the exercises and the lymph drainage every day as part of a general exercise regime and the swelling has gone completely down. I'm hoping to be told at my next lymph clinic appt that I can leave the sleeve off sometimes.  I also had shoulder problems - not caused by the lymphodema, but could have been cured by a steroid injection. They wouldn't give me the injection because of the lymphodema. I was told not to allow blood to be taken from the bad arm or blood pressure taken, or any injections and I have a type of medic alert bracelet to wear. Again it's exercise that has had a good effect, and my movement is much much better.
Posts.Title: Lymph node surgery

Posts.Content: Yesterday, for the first time in ages, I woke up feeling good - no pain.Trouble is, when I get days like that I ruin it all by doing too much!! And so I did it again yesterday. Spent the morning doing loads of washing and hanging out on the line - beautiful day here and it all dried really well. Made soup for lunch, and after a 10 minute sit down decided to take the old dog to the beach. Pushed her into the car - can't lift her so she has to ride in the passenger footwell. Walked to the end of the beach and did a sort of body scan - where mentally I checked myself over to see how I was feeling. result was good, but don't go too much further! So walked round the car park climbed over the wall again and back on to the beach. Felt as though I had my second wind, still felt good when we got back to the car. After a cup of tea did my stretching exercises (yoga-ish type) and sat on the bed for a rest before supper and then out to choir. A really busy energetic day for me!!   Today I had another walk!! To the woods this time as still feeling pretty good. Photo really is from my walk, the signs really are up in our woods - don't think the council could have put them there!! See what tomorrow brings - it's Thursday so it's my dance exercise class - hope I don't collapse from doing too much as I really enjoy the class. Hope the photo has come out okay - first time I've tried it!!!
Posts.Title: Walking back to Happiness

Posts.Content: Just wanted to add that breast cancer treatment has moved on a long way since 1977. There are treatments you can have now that simply weren't around then, and many, many more women are living longer because of them. It's all very frightening at the moment, but once you know what will be happening you will be better able to cope. I found that just concentrating on getting through one thing at a time was what worked for me.
Posts.Title: I'm so scared

Posts.Content: All the way through my treatment - chemo, surgery and radiotherapy, I've been given numbers to call in an emergency. During chemo I had 2 numbers. - one for the chemo ward where I was treated, which was for during the day on weekdays, and then an emergency number which was 24/7, for a different hospital, which I used a few times when I wasn't well over the weekend. It was comforting to know that it was covered every day, for 24 hours, made me feel looked after. Like ChrissieC I'm a bit surprised this isn't the case everywhere, and makes me think I've had really good care throughout.
Posts.Title: June Chemo Club

Posts.Content: I think I got lucky with the nails. My finger nails grow pretty fast - I always seem to be cutting them and the ridges have all disappeared so fingers crossed I'm okay there. I put some oil from H&B on them, don't know if that made a difference. My toenails are horrible. The tops of about 4 of them have flaked off, which isn't too bad cos there was new nail underneath, and I'm waiting for the nails on my big toes to fall off - any day now for one of them, from the look of it. Hair. I'm trying the "no poo" system and so far it's not been too bad. It all still feels like baby fluff, and it's growing a bit unevenly, but I'm getting it cut for the second time on Friday. It's come back almost completely white, with a few bits of darker colour. Someone told me it was "very Judi Dench"!!!! At least I now look as though I've got some hair and am much happier going out without my wig, wearing hats instead to protect from the sun.
Posts.Title: neddys/moaning cows club !!!!

Posts.Content: I've heard of this, not for aches and pains but for helping to prevent cancer. The article Dreamthief has mentioned says that research is showing that turmeric is showing promise for treating and preventing cancer. More research needed! I've got a book that mentions turmeric and says that mixing it with black pepper and olive oil, to be stirred into soups, casseroles etc. is the most effective way to use it.
Posts.Title: Tumeric and aches and pains

Posts.Content: I found I could tolerate sparkling water, and tonic water. My chemo was in the winter so I had a lot of soup as well. Along with my usual drinks I found it added up quite well. Keep thinking about coconut water, tried it but don't really like it. Must try the ones mixed with fruit.
Posts.Title: Drinks

Posts.Content: Had my surgery just over two weeks ago, and not even considering driving yet. Keep feeling as though I ought to be doing more, but at the moment I'm exhausted after even the little bit of exercise I try to do. Fine around the house, but going out for the very short walk I try to do each day is tiring. I've got fluid in my arm which the surgeon says is probably a result of the surgery, but she's referred me to lymphoedema clinic just in case. Have to say that the fluid is not so bad in my hand since I've started to go out for a brief walk Must get the exercises sorted, I've got appt to see about radiotherapy next week and I need to be able to get my arm above my head by the time I start that.  Know what you mean about recovery in fits and starts. About 9 days after the op, and feeling pretty yucky,  I woke up one morning suddenly feeling a lot better and more positive. Also seeing slight improvements day by day, eg I'm up and about all day now and not needing pain killers until the afternoon, when I start to get a bit tired and it all starts hurting again. So, onwards and upwards!!
Posts.Title: Feels as if I am going backwards a bit

Posts.Content: Wearing flight socks is a sensible precaution anyway regardless of whether you have had surgery or are on any of the BC drugs. It's recommended in general if you are sitting for any long periods of time and can't get up to move around a lot. If you are concerned your breast care nurse or GP should be able to help with advice. In my case I had a DVT at the beginning of my chemotherapy so shall be taking lots of precautions next time I fly.
Posts.Title: Flight stockings

Posts.Content: I've been told to wear my compression sleeve for flying too. I've always worn flight socks if going on a long journey - have done 24 hour coach journeys in the past and they were essential for those. I got fluid in my arm after the surgery and got referred to a lymphoedema clinic, I wear a compression sleeve every day so would automatically wear it for flying. I don't think you need to get one if you don't have lymphoedema
Posts.Title: Flight stockings

Posts.Content: Have you thought about trying a chiropractor or osteopath? I've been going to a chiropractor for years, and she keeps me mobile (most of the time), and pain free (again, most of the time). They should give you a consultation appointment, and a good chiropractor should tell you whether your pain is something they can help with. An osteopath should do the same thing. Acupuncture might help too. Re the ibuprofen gel. Best ask the pharmacy but if you are already taking ibuprofen based tablets then I'd have thought not having the gel as well.
Posts.Title: Ideas on coping with backache....

Posts.Content: Just joined and seen your post. I had a mastectomy last Tuesday, and, like you I was terrified. I had it done as a day case, I was the first one on the list and the anaesthetist and the surgeon came to see me beforehand and everyone was lovely. When I woke up in the recovery room I had a nurse sitting with me and she stayed beside me until I was completely awake and ready to be transferred to the ward. For a couple of hours I had waves of sleepiness sweeping over me, then I was given a cup of tea and a biscuit and my husband came to pick me up. I was home by about 5.30. Had a very dry mouth and my throat was a bit sore from the tube they use for the anaesthetic. Also had a drain, which was a pain as I kept thinking I was going to pull it out by accident. I got through it by remembering why it had to be done, and tried not to dwell on it too much. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Mastectomy on Monday and really scared!

Posts.Content: Drain came out Friday, thank goodness. Much easier without it. Would love to say I'm feeling fine with no pain, but that wouldn't be true. Pretty uncomfortable at the moment and having to keep the pain relief going but it's early days yet.

Posts.Title: Flight stockings

Posts.Content: Hi jonquile Don't get too despondent. I've just started my radiotherapy - day 3 today - but I wasn't able to have the CT scan at first because of shoulder and arm problems and not being able to get my arm into the right position. I had to go back 4 times before they were able to do the CT scan. I had pretty intensive physiotherapy on my arm and shoulder muscles and I saw a chiropractor too. I should get on to your BC nurse and explain what's happened and ask about physio as soon as possible. Ask if your hospital also provides acupuncture, some do, if you think that might help I was also advised by the radiography team to make sure I was tanked up with pain killers before I went for the CT scan. At one attempt the consultant came up to see me and said that they can give a shot of morphine as a last resort. I can only just get my arm into the right position for the radiotherapy now as my shoulder and arm are still not right,  but they've said again that if it gets too difficult again I can have morphine.  For Monday I'd suggest you take some really powerful painkillers if you can - I take either tramadol and ibuprofen together, or cocodamol and ibuprofen together. Don't worry too much about it, it must be something they come across quite often and they have strategies for getting over it.  Talk to your BC, or radiotherapy consultant.
Posts.Title: ctscan

Posts.Content: Hi, I read that there's no real scientific proof, but there's lots of hearsay evidence of their effectiveness. Epsom salt baths are supposed to release toxins from your body, and lots of people swear by them. Anyway, a nice warm bath is going to help relieve aching muscles and joints and I think that if you believe that the epsom salts are helping then they probably are. Himalayan pink bath salt is supposed to be really good too. Lots of chemists sell them I have some of both and would dearly love to have a bath with them. Unfortunately I now find it very hard to get out of the bath - I had a couple of "dry runs" a while ago and needed help to get out, so haven't tried the real thing yet. Problem for me is putting my weight on the side I had the mastectomy and pushing myself upwards out of the bath.  Your regime sounds really good, specially the water. Every therapist I speak to tells me to drink more and more water - I shall be spending all day in the loo at this rate!
Posts.Title: Continuing tips in combating Letroxole SE's

Posts.Content: Hi, I had my radiotherapy after surgery, so not quite the same situation as you. The time between them was nearly twelve weeks. The consultant initially said 6 weeks after the surgery, but I had issues with getting my arm into the right position and so it was nearly twelve weeks. I should speak to your oncologist and get him to tell you why he wants it to start so quickly. If it's just an administrative thing then I should ask for a couple of weeks delay, then you can enjoy your holiday, but if it's for medical reasons then I think I'd consider postponing the holiday  for a while until you are feeling better from the radiotherapy.
Posts.Title: Delaying radiotherapy for a few weeks - could it be detrimental?

Posts.Content: Sorry Mumra, but I don't know. I did ask at one of my failed CT attempts whether the 12 weeks was a medical or a funding issue, but they didn't really answer me. I think they like to get planning as soon as you have recovered sufficiently from the surgery. It may be different in different health trusts.
Posts.Title: ctscan

Posts.Content: Hi jonquile, how did you get on today? Did you manage to lie on the table okay?
Posts.Title: ctscan

Posts.Content: I was given a topical oestrogen cream for vaginal dryness some years ago. When I saw a different doctor a while later she nearly blew her top when she saw I'd been prescribed it. I now have Replens which very definitely does not contain oestrogen.
Posts.Title: Letrozole, hair thinning and shaving

Posts.Content: I was told the radiotherapy had to start within 12 weeks after my surgery. Mine started exactly 12 weeks later, and if I still hadn't been able to get my arm in place they had a Plan B ready, but it would have gone ahead somehow, regardless. Your consultant needs to know you're having problems and I'm sure your BC nurse will let him/her know. With me the CT people emailed the consultant and arranged it so that I was there so that he could come and see me and see exactly what the problem was. I was very upset that time too, just lay on the table with tears pouring down my face the whole time - not a good look! Hope your BC nurse reassures you.
Posts.Title: ctscan

Posts.Content: Hi littlesusie Are you being treated for lymphodema? If so I wonder if waiting quite a while to see if the swelling goes down, and stays down would be a good idea before having the ring resized, otherwise you may find that it will be too big when the swelling eventually subsides.  I had fluid in my arm and hand after my surgery - still not 100% certain it is lymphodema, but treating it as though it is. I went to the lymphodema clinic and got fitted for a compression sleeve, and a glove. I wear the sleeve every day, all day usually. I also do exercises, some given me by the lymph clinic, some I've picked up from other sources, and I religiously do these every day. The swelling in my hand disappeared very quickly, and to look at it you'd say there is no fluid there at all, although I think there is the tiniest amount there. Mine was in my right arm so my wedding ring wasn't affected. I think you've done the right thing to take it off. Sounds painful having it removed. Did the jeweller have to cut it?
Posts.Title: Had a bit of a traumatic morning

Posts.Content: Littlesusie , there is a booklet by Macmillan about lymph oedema, and it's got a couple of exercises in it. You can access it online. I was given a sheet by the lymph clinic with instructions on how to do simple lymphatic drainage, there are 12 steps to it. I can't find it online, but it includes some deep breathing and moving the skin gently to help the fluid drain away from the swollen area. There are also hints on posture and things you can do while you're sitting down watching television or whatever. I'm sure that doing the arm exercises will help your hand. I was horrified when my hand swelled. I earn a bit of money by playing the piano, and absolutely couldn't have swollen fingers, so I make sure I do hand exercises even though there is now no swelling. I'm not sure I can work out how to do a link otherwise I'd put some here, not sure if it's the right thing to do to offer you a copy of my simple lymph drainage, but I'm happy to do so if you want to contact me on a private message. I'd certainly ask your lymph nurse for some exercises though. Don't feel I've been very helpful here, but there's a lot you can do to control the swelling.

Posts.Title: A few tips from my Cancer Survivorship Course

Posts.Content: i've finished my rads now - just over a week ago, but I have some shooting pains in the breast area that started quite soon after the first session. I was told to put cream on the radiated area straight away, they didn't recommend anything but I said I had aqueous cream and E45 and they said that was fine. I got a bit of a rash with E45 so have ended up using Aveeno cream. I think the main thing is to use unperfumed cream that is as plain as possible, and to keep it moisturised right from the beginning. Aloe Vera is good if it feels hot. Some units seem to recommend specific creams so it might be best to check if yours does, but I would advise you to start moisturising now

Posts.Content: Hi My bones are thinner than they should be too; I've been prescribed something called Calcigran, it's calcium and and vitamin D3. I take them twice a day, and they can be chewed or sucked. Haven't been given Alendronic acid yet, don't like the sound of it, but will be checking whether I ought to have it when I see the consultant in a few weeks time for my follow up from the radiotherapy.

Posts.Content: I was offered treatment in either Taunton or Bristol. I live halfway between the two but chose Bristol. If you are having the planning in Bristol I'd have thought they'd give you the treatment there, or at least offered it to you.  Although the RT did make me tired I wasn't too tired to drive, and drove to Bristol and back each day. I do know that some people travel long distances to get to their RT, and some have to go by public transport, so it's doable but not ideal. Ask your BC nurse to find out if you can choose to have your treatment in Bristol. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Well done! I used to measure how I was improving by all these little benchmarks -  the first time I was able to raise a spoon to my mouth with my surgery arm to drink my soup, first time I could lift my arm to switch the light out etc. The most recent has been being able to get my arm behind my back and raise it enough to undo a bra fastening, and to be able to wipe myself after going to the loo! Hope this is not TMI!
Posts.Title: Little things - just need to say it

Posts.Content: After my surgery I didn't get the scar area wet for weeks!!! Didn't have external stitches, they stuck me together with glue. I think I must have reeked! There was no reason why I shouldn't have showered properly, but it all hurt so much  and I couldn't bear to look at it or have anything touch it. I developed a complicated way of washing that involved getting into the shower, with my nightie still on, and showering my bottom half, using the shower hand held, with nightie knotted around my waist to stop it getting wet. Then I used a sponge to wash my top half, but avoiding the surgery area. I'm 10  weeks post surgery now and it doesn't hurt so much, but the scar area is very uncomfortable. Managing to have a proper shower now though so at least I don't smell any more! It does all get easier
Posts.Title: Results.....waiting and sore!!!

Posts.Content: Some people have radiotherapy before surgery, some after. I had chemotherapy followed by surgery and I haven't started my radiotherapy yet. I think they like to leave approx 6 weeks after surgery before starting radiotherapy so you'll have some time to heal first. I'm now 10 weeks after surgery and waiting to start the radiotherapy -I've had some problems that have delayed it. Agree with advice re not Googling - you'll just frighten yourself. Baby wipes are wonderful, take things easy, it takes  some people quite a while to recover. Bestest advice I can give is make sure you do your exercises.
Posts.Title: Results.....waiting and sore!!!

Posts.Content: Hi It really shouldn't pinch - mine is really comfortable - I do get some small crease lines around the inside of my.elbow but they aren't sore. In one of my appointments I was told that I was borderline for getting a small size sleeve - some of my measurements were within the range for a small size - I normally have a medium. They suggested I try it and see if it was okay. It wasn't. I ripped the thing off after quite a short while; it felt as though my circulation had been cut off. Maybe yours should be the next size up? I also found that I wasn't quite putting my sleeve on properly so I asked the nurse to watch me put it on, and she pointed out a couple of things I wasn't doing properly. Can you ask your nurse to check you are putting it on correctly? I've noticed that different makes of sleeve feel different on me - some are tighter than others, even though they are the same class and size. The ones I have are Jobst. I have two prescribed every 6 months and I usually but at least one more from the Daylong website. I find them really comfortable. Hope you get to sort it out.

Posts.Title: BCN chat

Posts.Content: I'm interested in this too. I'd had floaters for a couple of years before getting BC, they didn't bother me much - the optician told me she couldn't see anything irregular in my eyes, and that my brain would learn to filter them out, which it did. However, after I had finished all my treatment (chemo, surgery, radiotherapy) but just before I started taking Anastrozole I suddenly started to get flashing lights in my peripheral vision and the floaters got more prominent. My brain has filtered out the floaters again so they don't bother me most of the time, but the peripheral flashes are still there 18 months later. They don't bother me during the day, but I'm very aware of them when it's dark. It can't be the Anastrozole that causes them in my case. I have to go to the opthalmic dept in the hospital every year to have my eyes checked out as I'm borderline glaucoma, and last time I went I mentioned them. He said the flashes are either an optical migraine, or the natural degeneration of something in my eyes due to age, but your post has made me wonder if they could have been caused by chemo, or radiotherapy!
